case_vignette: A 71-year-old male with a past medical history of poorly controlled diabetes and heart transplant is noted to have fevers and a black eschar on the nose on day 41 of hospitalization in the ICU. The patient is intubated and unable to provide history. Nurses report the area was first noticed to be darker and then rapidly expanded. Review of current medications include cyclosporine, tacrolimus, insulin, and broad spectrum antibiotics. Physical examination reveals an extensive dark black, necrotic eschar on the nasal bridge and left nasal sidewall, cheek, and lip with surrounding pink erythema. Oral examinatination reveals black eschars on upper palate.
question: What is the final diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I am experiencing fevers and have a black, dead tissue area on my nose, cheek, and lip, with some redness around these areas.
When did you first notice these symptoms?
The darker area was first noticed on day 41 of my hospitalization in the ICU.
Have you been diagnosed with any conditions or been on any particular treatments that might compromise your immune system?
Yes, I have a history of a heart transplant and have been taking medications like cyclosporine and tacrolimus which suppress the immune system.
Final Diagnosis: Mucormycosis
